title: Justice Department Issues Guidance on ‘Inability to Repay’ Claims
text:
The U.S. Justice Department on Tuesday issued guidance for federal prosecutors to use in cases where companies claim they can’t pay a criminal fine.

The move is designed to give prosecutors and companies more transparency around what to expect in cases where financially troubled companies are faced with criminal penalties, Assistant Attorney General Brian Benczkowski said in prepared remarks ahead of a speech at a New York conference for white-collar defense lawyers.

“Our aim is for companies to work diligently to deter criminal wrongdoing before it ever needs the attention of the Department of Justice, but also to make wise decisions about how to approach us when things do go wrong,” Mr. Benczkowski, who leads the department’s criminal division, said in the prepared remarks.

Negotiations between prosecutors and companies are typically confidential. In one recent case, involving Odebrecht SA, the Justice Department appeared to accept the Brazillian company’s claims that it could not pay a $4.5 billion fine. The fine was to be split between governments in the U.S., Brazil and Switzerland. U.S. prosecutors agreed to subject the fine to an inability-to-repay analysis at a later date.

The guidance issued Tuesday instructs prosecutors to look at several considerations when assessing a company’s claims, including its ability to raise capital and factors that led to its financial condition. Prosecutors are also encouraged to consider whether a possible fine could affect a company’s ability to pay restitution to victims, according to the guidance.

In making their assessments, prosecutors are expected to collect information on a company’s financial picture, including its cash flow, operating budget and divestiture plans. If prosecutors determine that a company cannot pay, they may recommend a lower fine or the implementation of an installment schedule.

The guidelines “help ensure that prosecutors stick to a more uniform set of considerations, and also that companies looking to resolve matters have greater insight into how prosecutors think,” Mr. Benczkowski said.

Additionally, the Justice Department has renamed and reorganized its Securities and Financial Fraud Unit. It will now be known as the Market Integrity and Major Frauds Unit and will include five teams that focus on securities, commodities, government procurement, financial institutions and consumer fraud, respectively, Mr. Benczkowski said.
